content: How can I help you today?
I’ve been struggling to sleep, and it’s starting to affect everything else in my life. My partner suggested I talk to someone, so here I am. Honestly, I’m not sure if this will help.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like your sleep struggles have been weighing heavily on you and are impacting different areas of your life. It’s understandable to feel unsure about whether talking like this will make a difference, but the fact that you’re here shows a willingness to explore your options—you’ve already taken a positive step. Can you tell me more about how the sleep challenges are affecting you?

Yeah, it’s been tough. I can’t focus at work because I’m so tired, and I’m afraid I might mess something up and get fired. At night, I just lie awake thinking about everything—bills, work problems, my kids. It feels endless, and I don’t know how to stop it.

That sounds overwhelming. Being tired and unable to focus during the day, while lying awake at night with your thoughts racing—it makes sense that this would feel endless and stressful. It seems like there’s a lot on your plate right now, with responsibilities like work, bills, and family to think about. It’s clear that you care deeply about those areas of your life. What do you think might be making the nights especially difficult for you?

I think at night it’s just so quiet, and there’s nothing to distract me from my thoughts. During the day, I can keep busy, but when I’m lying in bed, everything I’m worried about just hits me all at once. I try looking at my phone to distract myself, but it doesn’t help—it just makes things worse, honestly.

It’s no wonder the quiet nights can feel overwhelming, especially when worries come flooding in and there’s no distraction to keep your mind off them. It seems like you’ve tried using your phone to manage those thoughts, and while it hasn't helped, it shows you’re searching for ways to cope. It sounds like these thoughts and worries are persistent—what’s your sense of what might help shift things for you, even just a little?

Honestly, I don’t know. I’ve tried to calm myself down or think about other things, but my brain just won’t shut off. I know using my phone is probably a bad habit, but I don’t know what else to do in the moment—it’s like I need something to distract me from feeling so overwhelmed.

It sounds like you’ve been doing your best to navigate those overwhelming feelings and find some relief, even though it's been hard to calm your mind. It’s understandable to reach for something like your phone in those moments—it’s familiar and feels like a way to distract yourself. You’re trying, which really matters. It also sounds like you’re open to exploring other ways to handle these moments. If anything were possible, what might relief from that overwhelm look like for you?

It would look like actually being able to shut my brain off at night—like just being calm enough to fall asleep without feeling like I’m drowning in my own thoughts. I wouldn’t need to stare at my phone or search for distractions. I’d just… rest. Honestly, it feels so far away right now that I can’t even imagine how to get there.

Being able to just rest without the constant wave of thoughts sounds like a peaceful goal, and it makes sense that falling asleep calmly feels far away right now. You’ve been carrying a lot, and those racing thoughts at night seem to be tied to how much you’re juggling each day. Even though it feels distant, your ability to articulate this vision of calm shows that it’s on your mind and meaningful to you. What do you think makes imagining that change feel so out of reach?

It just feels like there’s so much to handle, and I don’t know where to start. My worries about work, money, and my family feel never-ending, so calming down enough to sleep feels impossible. No matter what I try, my brain keeps coming back to everything that could go wrong.

It sounds like the weight of your responsibilities is making it hard to find a place to start, especially when your mind keeps circling back to all the “what-ifs.” When worry becomes a constant loop, it can feel like there’s no way forward. You’re navigating some really tough emotions right now, but you’ve already taken steps by reflecting on this and seeking out help. What do you think you need most in this moment—to ease the pressure or perhaps take a small step toward change?

I honestly don’t even know what I need. Maybe to feel like I have some control over all of this? It’s hard to think clearly when everything feels so overwhelming. I just want to feel like I’m making progress instead of being stuck in this cycle.

Wanting to feel like you have some control and are moving forward makes a lot of sense. When everything feels overwhelming and stuck, it’s natural to crave even a small step in the right direction. You’ve already made some progress by sharing what’s been weighing on you and reflecting on what might help. What would it look like to take just one small step toward breaking this cycle?

Maybe starting small could help, but I’m not sure what that step would even be. I guess I could try putting my phone away earlier at night or writing things down to get them out of my head, but I don’t know if it’ll work. It’s just hard to figure out how to actually put any of this into action.

Thinking about options like avoiding your phone at night or writing things down is a big step—it shows you’re considering ways to ease your mind. Trying something small, even if you’re unsure how effective it might be, is a starting place, and that matters because it’s movement toward change. Before we talk through putting it into action, is there anything else on your mind about what’s been making this cycle feel so hard?

I think the hardest part is just feeling like no matter what I do, nothing will actually fix the bigger stressors, like work or money. Even if I try something small, it doesn’t change the fact that those worries are still there. It’s just hard to believe that anything I try will really make a difference.

It makes sense that the bigger stressors—work, money, and everything else—feel so heavy, and it’s hard to believe that taking smaller steps could ease those pressures. When those big worries weigh on you constantly, it can feel like no solution will truly make a difference. You’ve shown so much insight into what’s making this difficult, and even though it feels daunting, you’re reflecting thoughtfully on what change could look like. Would you like to explore ways to address these smaller steps, or focus more on finding support to handle those bigger worries?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
